review_detail: It's the interaction of a sanguine realism with a celebration of the liberating effect of the imagination that makes the magic happen. That, and the exquisite animation.

This film, directed by Mark Osborne is multi-layered, with a story about a writer, an aviator, the Little Prince, and a young, modern day girl, who becomes friends with the aviator and who searches for the Little Prince told in the aviator's story.
Perhaps it's best to think of it less as an adaptation and more as an appreciation of what the book has meant to the world since its initial publication.
It is deeply personal and profoundly moving, a sensitive and affecting portrait of humanity.
A very intelligent update of a classic that contributes by creating a whole new world. [Full review in Spanish]
Even though it's not a literal adaptation, respects the book by developing in different layers. [Full review in Spanish]
A wonderfully creative, soul-soothing work.
There is both a fragility and immediacy to the imagery-as if watching it might give you a paper cut.
It can't help but be compared to the daring, challenging original.

An instant classic for young and old, the film capitalizes on the themes of identity, what it means to grow up and the importance of staying curious with a gusto and enthusiasm that matches the film's young lead.
Taken as one piece of art, as one beautiful, self-sustaining creation, this Little Prince is a thing of beauty.

The film is admirable for its gentle hand when it comes to difficult subjects like the ephemeral nature of life, and its bold visual style, but it's also a film whose final reel seems unwilling to recognize the realities of its own story.
If Saint-Exupéry offered readers a petite, queer-tasting square of some delicate cake they'd never heard of, Netflix has served up a familiar, fragrant, well-balanced meal.
The Little Prince should make a compelling, if not always fully incisive, case for clinging to the lessons of youth.
The animation is gorgeous, with contemporary home life scenes in CGI and the world of The Little Prince in stunning stop-motion design.
Saint-Exupery's core themes are never lost despite the contemporary context; rather they are enhanced by the Aviator's memories and the Little Girl's fresh experiences.
The classic scenes redone gave me chills; the new stuff made me facepalm.
...one of the most inspired, delightful animations of the year.

Though it takes liberties with the source material, The Little Prince enriches the novella on which it is based, developing its themes and characters into one of the best animated releases of the year.
Just lovely and poignant and all the other adjectives that make one's heart swell.
The French literature classic reinvents itself for the 21st century with all the warmth and cleverness of the original tale. [Full review in Spanish]
Mark Osborne brings the innocence of the story and characters created by Saint-Exupéry. [Full review in Spanish]
A cute and entertaining movie that will make viewers discover (or rediscover) tha magic of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's book. [Full review in Spanish]
There is a faith that the story and characters will keep the audience engaged, even if there isn't a bright and shiny thing to distract them in a every single scene.

...for the most part the director takes the right liberties, ending up with an extremely beautiful, very charming, thematically rich take that's sure to be one of the better animated movies this year.
This is a very good-looking film that represents a brave attempt to do justice to a very popular book; it manages it, just.
This heartfelt bauble about a young girl facing the pressures of adulthood is constantly enlivened by its beautiful images, even if one itches for a narrative that's a little less rudimentary.

Adds all manner of narrative bells and whistles to the author's slender, lyrical story of friendship between a pilot and a mysterious extraterrestrial voyager, but stays true to its timeless depiction of childhood wonderment ...
Children and grown-ups who watch with their hearts will be rewarded with a very sweet film.
A whimsical journey in favour of following dreams and finding life's true loves - a film for young audiences as well as for the oldies who've lost their way.
This first feature screen animation of The Little Prince is a pleasure to behold, but as with any journey the venture is not without risk.
To be fair, this homage to The Little Prince is a lovely story, lovingly told. And for the first two-thirds of the movie, it feels like one of the freshest animated films in ages.

Saint-Exupéry's darker tones and intense emotions are all here, echoing the Little Girl's own self-discovery in a dual narrative that dares to be more evocative and sophisticated than children are accustomed to.
The makers of this animated update of The Little Prince approach Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's classic with respect and imagination, with initially satisfying results.
A gorgeously animated, poignant homage to the relationship people have formed over the years with Antoine St Exupery's book about the wonder that is childhood.

While the scenes with the little prince and the aviator are whimsically charming, they fail to make up for the framing plot's trivialization of the source material, undermining the original story's beguiling, tragic quality.
An homage to the story writen by Antione de Saint-Exupéry, but mostly to those readers who have connected with the book. [Full review in Spanish]
Osbornes reinvention of the classic French story lands as a beautiful anecdote full of endearing and magical characters. [Full review in Spanish]
A wonderful, fresh and endearing adaptation. [Full review in Spanish]
A wonderful and emotional animated film that has the essence of the novel and reinterprets it for new generations, bringing the story to a whole new audience. [Full review in Spanish]
It's a relief to realize that there are great animation films to be made outside of Pixar, films that stimulate the imagination of both children and adults alike. [Full Review in Spanish]
The quality in the animation, the story and depth of the characters, make this movie a great movie that will not only be loved by kids, but also adults. [Full review in Spanish]
An emotional, inspiring and touching homage to Antoine Saint-Exupéry's work. [Full review in Spanish]
The film is the antidote to a grown-up world. [Full review in Spanish]
A great exercise full of creativity and beauty that celebrates and expands the universe created by Saint-Exupéry. [Full review in Spanish]
It's a relief knowing that not only Pixar can make amazing animated films that capture the imagination of kids and adults alike. [Full review in Spanish]
One of the best films of the year. [Full review in Spanish]
A totally visual experience that feels a bit repetitive thematically.
A strange, satisfying, star-studded adaptation of the kid lit classic.
At its inventive best-like the creation of a little cloth fox who never speaks but steals almost every scene he's in-it does capture the odd, tender wonder of [Saint-Exupéry's] world.
The whole movie's done with great skill and artistry, and while some of the original story's more philosophical moments have been toned down, they haven't disappeared.
Better ... to think of this handsome, inoffensive Little Prince less as an adaptation than as a tribute-one that makes the relationship between the book and those who love it a central focus.
Both parts of the movie work well, but they don't always work well together, especially in the final act.
There's a lot of charm, thought and feeling in this film version. It expands on the original without dishonoring it.
This inventive adaptation of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's children's book is beautifully realized in CG and stop-motion animation techniques.
A wonderful surprise.
I'd tell you to watch The Little Prince for its enchanting animation alone. That it's poignant, thoughtful, and warmly thrilling, that's just icing.
A film that everyone should be happy to show their children.
Osborne's take on The Little Prince shows a reverence for the original story, plus an understanding of what modern audiences want with a more linear story and bright animation.
This terrific adaptation of the beloved children's book for adults features a passel of Hollywood voices, but they're beside the point.
An ambitious gamble that looks like a sure bet commercially but which, artistically, shortchanges its source material.

Mark Osborne's feature-length adaptation adds a dominant frame story that, at first, plays off the famous little fable (splendidly animated) within it quite nicely, only to overwhelm the original in its action-adventure third act.
Even if the kids are left wanting more, purists will doubtless be pleased with Mark Osborne's reverential take on Antoine de Saint-Exupery's 1943 tale.
Perhaps "The Little Prince" isn't the direct take on the novella fans may be expecting, but with relaxed expectations, there's exceptional artistry and profound meaning to examine.
As preachy and repetitive as The Little Prince can be, it offers enough moments of poetry to keep it flirting with greatness, or at least goodness.

In a time where films and television shows are lauded for how "faithful" they are in adapting another person's work, I think what The Little Prince accomplishes is more impressive - a tribute, true to its source material and original unto itself.

It won't destroy your precious memories of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's classic, but you may feel a frisson of betrayal in the final moments that forces you to scan the bookcase back home for the original. Just to recapture that alien feeling.
If what is essential is invisible to the eye, then The Little Prince has accomplished the impossible; it has made the invisible visible, and in 3D no less.
No child, or adult, for that matter, will be able to resist the considerable charm of The Little Prince.
Director Mark Osborne [achieves] some charming effects... But the computer-animated portions that function as a real-world framing device are more tedious than fanciful.

The Little Prince depends on its viewers' willingness to go along with twee flutterings like "The stars are beautiful because of a flower that cannot be seen." I'm too much of an adult to swallow that saccharine bilge, I guess.

It's a film with charm and sweetness, but for me is structurally encumbered by this new present-day narrative level: the smarter, zappier modern animated style makes the marionette-style images of the past look a bit low-octane and quaint.
Osborne respects the integrity of the original story in this charming adaptation.

Beautifully and expressively animated, The Little Prince basically is the story of an old man who still acts like a kid and a kid who's being programmed to be an "essential" cog in the grand industrial, soul-deadening scheme of things.
The Little Prince is a beautiful tribute to a timeless book.
Lovely, slow, nostalgic and a bit over-rated.
It's part-adaptation, part fan-fiction, part update. But it doesn't forsake the original.
Animated take on classic tale is sweet but restrained.
A delight for children and adults alike until it sadly spirals out of control in its overly ambitious finale.
The Little Prince is a fond tribute, true to its source material and original unto itself.
There are only a few ... delightful moments in an otherwise muddled movie that feels like three films ineptly grafted together.

"The Little Prince" is really a movie within a movie; the author's delicate, fanciful story is folded into a harsh, modernist commentary on depersonalization and conformity in the contemporary workplace.
Mr. Osborne has done himself proud. What's essential in his film is the singular beauty of the first half.
The film comes across as an homage and extravagant promo for the book.

When the film hews to its source material, the results are enchanting, but the predictable and sentimental framing device around the slim tale undercuts the potency of the book's meditations on love and mortality.
As fragile and beautiful as the beloved rose guarded by the wee fellow of the title.
A creative and spiritual reworking of Antoine de Saint-Exupery's magical and enlightening 1943 novella.
We've yet to get a masterpiece-level film adaptation of the classic novella The Little Prince, but if and until that day comes, this will do just nicely, thank you very much.
